ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Overview of sociogenomics and applications to genetic studies; overview of statistical methods for conducting sociogenomics research (coding in R and data manipulation in Plink2, which is a command line tool).

The course was a really good introduction into the field of sociogenomics. I developed insights into the statistical methods used to analyse genetic data. There were a lot of really interesting discussions around the role of genes in social outcomes, genetic tendencies, assortative mating, genes-environment interaction and ethical considerations in this field.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths -- good readings, and assignments follow from class lectures very clearly. You'll learn a lot!
Weaknesses -- none really, although the final project can be a little difficult since it requires you to engage with very high-level sociogenomics research that can be hard to understand.

The instructor was a great strength to the course as her interest and enthusiasm for both, the content and teaching, really came through. It also really helped that it was a smaller class size which enabled free conversation and insightful discussions. The assignments were also a great way for checking our learning at each level of the class. The independent coding at the beginning of the class, especially in PLINK was a little tricky but I was able to catch up after some time. It would also be helpful if the class was recorded, in case we were unable to attend a class and wanted to catch up after. Overall, it was a great class, I learned so much from it and the instructor was incredible.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Professor Sotoudeh is great and the course is a really interesting extension of foundational work in data analysis. I will say that it'll help to have some prior knowledge of genetics (especially gene coding and polygenic scores), but it's not a requirement by any means.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this class - to both students from Yale college as well as graduate students. The field has wide ranging implications and could be of interest to individuals studying policy, sociology, public health, genomics, chronic diseases, law, etc. Every student will have a lot to learn from this nascent and upcoming field.
